@adriancole 
Yes, correct.
And this improves performance by avoiding calling `/api/v2/trace` API in trace page if not needed.
In other words, reuse results of `/api/v2/traces` API in the individual trace page.
@adriancole thanks very much. it works

Some notes from discussion with @tacigar 

I have service graph now, but I cannot tell if there is a problem with one node behavior
if I want to understand behavior of a single machine in a service, I cannot do this today.
this is because the edges are aggregatate (parent, child, count), based on service name, not any other information in the endpoint such as IP address.

This can make certain problems difficult to understand, such as if one node in a service is running the wrong code, or if a new version of code only deployed to one node is causing a problem.

So, if I have a way to classify by another means, I can identify this type of behavior. For example, IP address. {(parent, ip), (child, ip), count)  the dependency link has one more qualifier than before, for this example IP address.

There are now many more nodes.. because what was before just service-service is now (service,ip) -> (service, ip). Inside one trace, this could be fine because maybe not that many combinations


IP is just an example, user may want to explore by site tag like cluster or department or something else. The difference between this and normal dependency graph is we generate the links in javascript. This means we can aggregate by anything, not just service but also custom tag (like http.route).

Yes, this is still WIP.

@adriancole 
Many thanks for your feedback. We're constantly improving our product, so this kind of feedback is very valuable to us.

Ex the part to remove is the expansion here. You'll notice it is only luck that the traces of interest (expanded) are with only one trace between them. In simple traces like from zipkin server, only 4-7 spans, this looks benign, but you could imagine LINE and others have 800 span traces, so expanding them inline is not that useful. cc also @bulicekj
+1 because less screen overload.

ps there's a lot of history about ES_MAX_REQUESTS and why we moved to throttling instead. the short story is that the backlog in ES is unrelated to the concurrent connection count. It is the backlog that's the problem and you can overrun that with very few connections.
> I want to show root span information in search result list in Discover page (in #2656). Like this...

probably hard to start a test if one doesn't exist, but now would be a good time to add a test. our old codebase zipkin-ui got into a critical spot once where we had to do a lot of backfilling of tests and still never caught up.
OK, I'll add tests.

actually if you hit anything except the health endpoint first, it puts things into an unusable state. I think @anuraaga has some change in mind to fall back to unhealth checked names when health checking isn't complete yet. We need to solve this one way or another before release as when it is bad, most commands will return 503 and it isn't possible even to control-c out of it.

This happened because we moved the `await` out of `httpObject` into `check` I guess. I think I was expecting the `Storage` abstraction to call `check()` before issuing queries / spans, etc. Do you think such a change would make sense?
I think before we made a call to ensure the index templates existed before proceeding. if the health check is now a dependency, then it should be a dependency of checking for index templates.

I also think we will need to have a switch to turn off health checks because we may not have found all the quirks. we will want to be able to release zipkin soon, and there have been many odd things that seem to imply better safe to be able to either opt-into health checking or at least opt out of it.

for example I get these quirks even on my laptop, which seems off. I think it is because of use of "localhost" which then trips it into health checking loop. If there's only one IP resolved maybe better to not have health checking as an in-band requirement.

by in-band what I mean is that usually we don't require commands to route through the health checking device. We do have initialization dependencies, like make sure schema can be installed, but every thing I've run into about health check so far is red herring. I feel like we may have a catastrophe if we enable this by default to point where people won't want to upgrade. It might be better to make this opt-in until it isn't causing a lot of delay startup or hanging shutdown etc.
Yeah I think opt-in should be good until https://github.com/line/armeria/issues/1910 - hopefully that solves all the quirks
Though one thing, before that we should track down why an exception causes the server to hang - I think that would happen for any exception, here it just happens to be `EndpointGroupException`

one way is to allow "untrusted connection" until health check boots up as it takes a while anyway. I think this is a good idea regardless of adding a switch to disable things. Primarily because the timeouts we are hitting are way longer than normal ES stuff. If we have some tuning to do, we should do that in the background until things are not eggshell.

ex. first version has health checking opt-in and then after we prove it is stable etc, we have health checking enabled by default. I think we can get some sites like LINE to test with health check and show it is stable for example, but usually we have chicken egg problem with testing.

By disabling health check we can also get to the bottom of what all the hanging is about, as I've not even gotten reliable tracing in order yet.

I guess since with this change it will always fallback when there are no health checked endpoints, maybe we don't need an extra flag.

Also we might be seeing some non-IOException causing hangs

> I guess since with this change it will always fallback when there are no
> health checked endpoints, maybe we don't need an extra flag.
>
> Also we might be seeing some non-IOException causing hangs
>

I'm happy if hangs go away. Main thing is master isn't shippable until we
can get hang-free.
I plan to merge this on green because the code around logging may change a bit once I refactor some complexity in http call cloning

I think this is clearest if we add a logging parameter to the `ElasticsearchStorage` constructor so it can make sure to handle it appropriately (otherwise I guess we would need to add a qualifier to distinguish `Consumer<ClientBuilderOptions>`). Does that sound reasonable?

thanks.. good eye. I will also make a test to prove it.

@anuraaga I assigned to you as I'm mostly offline today and I don't think we should release the server while we get hung requests. Especially doing this on POST is dangerous because it can tie up reporter threads on clients until their timeout.

ps when we get to this spot, you can only `kill -9` the server

here is an example of hung requests. While this is probably a bug, it is the sort of thing that we should have some notes about in the "don't panic" guide. Because we have been looking carefully at code and yet somehow get to a place where server can't even stop. We need some tips on places to look when we accidentally make some small problem that causes this.

https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/2699

```bash
SELF_TRACING_ENABLED=true ES_HTTP_LOGGING=body STORAGE_TYPE=elasticsearch java -jar zipkin.jar
```

looks good. if we want to later change the headless/incomplete root span name, we have a test to change!

Thanks, so we do want commands to block until the template is correct. However, we don't want to block the server's ability to process requests or shutdown.

I'm guessing here we shouldn't be using eventLoop?
https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-server/src/main/java/zipkin2/server/internal/ZipkinHttpCollector.java#L110-L113

or is it that contextAwareExecutor is not something that will unblock the event loop?
https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-server/src/main/java/zipkin2/server/internal/ZipkinHttpCollector.java#L168

If you want to wait until `ensureIndexTemplates()` completes, you need to make sure it is run from a non-eventloop thread, such as `ctx.blockingTaskExecutor()`.

`ctx.contextAwareExecutor()` (or `contextAwareEventLoop()` is just a decorated version of `ctx.eventLoop()` which sets a thread-local context. You might want to use `ctx.makeContextAware(ctx.blockingTaskExecutor())` if you want to make `blockingTaskExecutor()` context-aware.

thanks for the tips trustin! I am boarding a flight now but this is great.

I initially tried an approach of eagerly initializing storage to get the blocking out of the way, but it means storage has to be up before zipkin server, which I guess we don't require.

For a bit more info, I think the deadlock happens when resolving DNS for the blocking HTTP request - we happen to be using a separate worker group for our client factory so usually requests would not actually deadlock. But our dns endpoint group is not configured with an event loop and uses the default - this is why even `orElse` didn't help here, because while the fallback isn't health checked, it is using DNS on a blocked event loop.

For now #2703 moves our span logic off of the event loop - going forward we'll want to see how we can make our async APIs actually async.

ps on the "really async" part let's not get too zealous. there is a lot of
value ensuring that the index template is actually installed. if that
implies blocking so be it.

definitions of async the one i am concerned with is a goal of async which
implies someone might accidentally sit on the event loop. we have several
external storage modules and their health checks work in many ways. just
want to be able to release software again

one thing we did recently was make sure calls to execute directly through a
base storage integration test. this was indirectly added during the
throttling work because the in memory storage was executing inline at call
construction time. blocking during call.enqueue is going to be possible
especially in third party.

until we can detect this and issue big warning, it is probably better to
not rely on enqueue being non blocking if the alternative is a server you
cant ctrl c out of and not know why.

It makes sense to keep things simple, especially given external composability, so keeping business logic on blocking executor threads makes sense too. Forget I ever mentioned async :P But I'd say in that case, our goal should be to remove the `enqueue` family of methods at some point - methods taking callbacks are a sign that they won't block the calling thread, but if that is actually possible, `execute` captures the fact that it may block more clearly and is easier to use to boot.

rag it isnt that they shouldn't be async it is that the repercussions
shouldn't change from meh to catastrophe in a minor release.

breaking api to remove async adds massive work everywhere and we are
forever stuck in infrastructure thrash as it is.

this is why I would suggest we be tolerant and then go and make things
nicer.

if we run in a mode that has catastrophic effects if async isnt really
async or not async enough. that mode must be optional because there is no
way we can support otherwise and the act of support isnt optional.

if it is a new version completely of the runtime.. fair game but in that
case if breaking api everywhere that is exactly the time to let async work
properly vs the other way around.

In brown field we have to transition and be careful about how we treat new
strictness. opt in like a new method that suggests super async not more
than 10us blocking or whatever the new contract is.. knowing that
contract.. testing that contract then leveraging it.

hope this makes sense.

Right we're on the same page - we wouldn't ever want to make a big API change in either direction in a minor release. Hence #2703 - and while I was planning on migrating other APIs to be on the event loop thinking enqueue doesn't block, now I know not to try that. 

This discussion is just to record options for where we may want to go at some point and hopefully providing extra knowledge and context for concepts used in Armeria along the way.
Just for tracking purposes, I believe it was #2633 that introduced Material UI

> And this improves performance by avoiding calling `/api/v2/trace` API in trace page if not needed.
> In other words, reuse results of `/api/v2/traces` API in the individual trace page.

I haven't thoroughly checked the implementation (sorry), but I'm wondering if a user wants to get the latest data from `/api/v2/trace` on the trace view screen, is there a way to do this? Does refreshing the web page do that? I can imagine in the case that the trace is in-progress when returned in the search results, a user will want a way to get the up-to-date trace data in the trace detail view.
I wonder if all users are using zipkin-dependencies spark jobs...

for this I mean aggregate the traces returned by /api/v2/traces in
javascript, via a port of DependencyLinker. In this way spark doesn't
matter.

> Sleuth defaults to 10% sampling. Do you mean changing that default
> sampling from 10% to 1 trace per second?
>

sleuth defaults aren't really important to us. yes, this is 1 trace per
second for self-tracing zipkin itself. percentage is a bad choice because
storage requests can amplify. we need a rate limit approach for
self-tracing when also tracing writes.

If it isn't practical to decouple the health check http config from the real http config, probably the better choice would be to have the health check config use tracing, but still unsampled. We can switch the headers to b3 single to lower the impact also. I want to be conscious of the amount of energy spent on health checking elasticsearch, which is more than some of our storage impls get at all :P
basically the most annoying thing is health checks polluting the output of ES_HTTP_LOGGING. by reverting the tracing back where it was, we can still accomplish the more important and visible change.

The combo of what you did here moving logging, and being less verbose in b3 headers via https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/2707 should be enough I think. Let's revert the tracing part and get this merged?
https://github.com/openzipkin/brave/issues/949 is related

Yup will clean it up by tomorrow. Also realized that IIUC https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/2700 should prevent the health check from being sampled since health check isn't in the context of a server request
